body.p:
Using a plain DITA map the transformation will produce a publication with a front page, a table of contents, chapters and contents, and at the end the index. This is appropriate for most cases, but sometimes you may need to:
remove the TOC or index
add a glossary
change the position of the TOC of the index relative to the neighbouring topics
add a preface, a font matter or a back matter with copyright notices, abstracts, etc. All these can be done using the DITA bookmaps.
A bookmap has a more elaborate structure. You should start by defining the title structure, with a main title and alternative title:
body.codeblock: <!DOCTYPE bookmap PUBLIC "-//OASIS//DTD DITA BookMap//EN" "bookmap.dtd"> <bookmap id="taskbook"> <booktitle> <mainbooktitle>Publication Title</mainbooktitle> <booktitlealt>A very short description of the publication</booktitlealt> </booktitle>
body.p: Then you may define a front matter. In this you may link the topics that need to appear before the main content. You may also define the location where the table of contents will be placed. In the example below, it appears between the "abstract" and "foreword" topics:
body.note: To remove the TOC from the publication, just omit the toc element from the booklists.
body.p: Next, the topics are grouped into chapters:

At the end you may define the structure of the back matter. Just like for the frontmatter, you may include some topics and some generated content, like the index. In the example below, we defined that the glossary should come after the index, followed by a list of figures and list of tables. At the very end we have some topic with some thank you notes.
body.codeblock:
<backmatter> <topicref href="topics/conclusion.dita"/> <booklists> <indexlist/>
<glossarylist> <topicref href="topics/xp.dita" keys="xp" print="yes" /> <topicref href="topics/anti_lock_braking_system.dita" keys="abs" print="yes" /> </glossarylist>
<figurelist/> <tablelist/> </booklists> <topicref href="topics/thanks.dita"/> </backmatter>
body.p: As you can see the bookmaps offer a much better control over the final content of the publication. It also gives more options in controlling the metadata that will go into the PDF, see the topic.
